question: Should the EU engage in further enlargement?

content.source_1: European Council President Charles Michel, Bled Strategic Forum speech (Aug. 28, 2023) — Calls enlargement a strategic imperative and urges the EU and candidates to be “ready” by 2030, framing expansion as essential for Europe’s security and resilience in the face of Russia’s aggression and geopolitical competition.
content.source_2: Politico Europe, “Enlargement would cost EU €256bn — internal document” (Sept. 2023) — Reports on a leaked EU analysis estimating that bringing in new members could require hundreds of billions in additional spending and major reallocations in CAP and cohesion funds, highlighting significant budgetary trade-offs and strains.
content.source_3: European Commission, DG ECFIN, “Five years of an enlarged EU — Economic achievements and challenges” (2009) — Finds that the 2004–2007 enlargements boosted growth, trade, and investment for both old and new member states, offering empirical evidence of economic gains from past expansion.
content.source_4: European Court of Auditors, Special Report (2022), “EU support for the rule of law in the Western Balkans: limited results so far” — Concludes that EU assistance has had limited effectiveness in improving rule of law in candidate countries, questioning the credibility of accession conditionality without stronger leverage or reforms.
content.source_5: European Commission, Standard Eurobarometer 100 (Autumn 2023), “Public Opinion in the European Union” — Shows EU‑wide support for further enlargement rising to around a majority (about 53%), with especially higher backing for Ukraine’s eventual membership, indicating shifting public sentiment in favor.
content.source_6: Franco‑German Expert Group on EU Institutional Reform, “Sailing on High Seas: Reforming and Enlarging the EU for the 21st Century” (Sept. 2023) — Argues that enlargement should proceed only alongside internal EU reforms (e.g., staged accession, budget changes, expanded qualified majority voting) to preserve functionality and legitimacy.
